what: Expected Value and Variance of Combined Variables
title: STAT1201 Course Notes
text: Suppose \(X\) random variable \(\) constant \[ \begin{aligned} Y &= aX \\ E(Y) &= aE(X)\\ Var(Y) &= ^2 Var(X) \end{aligned} \] Suppose \(X\) random variable \(\) \(b\) constants. \[ \begin{aligned} Y &= aX + b \\ E(Y) &= aE(X) + b\\ Var(Y) &= ^2 Var(X) \\ SD(Y) &= aSD(X) \end{aligned} \] Suppose \(X_1\) \(X_2\) two independent random variables. \[ \begin{aligned} Y &= X_1 + X_2 \\ E(Y) &= E(X_1) + E(X_2)\\ Var(Y) &=  Var(X_1) + Var(X_2) \end{aligned} \] Suppose \(X_1\) \(X_2\) two independent random variables. \[ \begin{aligned} Y &= X_1 - X_2 \\ E(Y) &= E(X_1) - E(X_2)\\ Var(Y) &=  Var(X_1) - Var(X_2) \end{aligned} \]

what: Sampling Distribution of the Sample Mean
title: STAT1201 Course Notes
text: distribution possible sample means using sample size, selected population. \(\mu = 162.1504\) \(\sigma = 8.147348\) can take 20 samples size n population can treat sample means (\(\overline{X}\)) random variable calculate mean standard deviation 20 sample means. can observe mean sample means closes population mean. standard deviation sample means becomes smaller. ratio standard deviation sample means population standard deviation \(\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\) population normally distributed, sampling distribution sample means (\(\overline{X}\)) normally distributed. Therefore distribution \(\overline{X}\) can summarized follows: \[ \begin{aligned} E(\overline{X}) &= \mu \\ Var(\overline{X}) &= \frac{\sigma^2}{n} \\ sd(\overline{X}) &= \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} \\ \therefore \overline{X} &\sim Norm(\mu, \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}) \end{aligned} \]

what: Sampling Distribution of the Sample Proportions
title: STAT1201 Course Notes
text: sample proportion (\(\hat{p}\)) Define \(p\) population proportion students whose height less equal 155cm \(\hat{p} = \frac{x}{n}\) x number students sample whose height less equal 155cm Provided \(n\) large \(np > 5\) \(n(1 - p) > 5\) can show , \[ \begin{aligned} E(\hat{p}) &= p \\ sd(\hat{p}) &= \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} \\ \therefore \hat{p} &\sim Norm(p, \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}}) \\ \\ Z &= \frac{\hat{p} - p}{\sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}}} \\ Z &\sim Norm(0, 1) \\ \end{aligned} \]

text: \(t\) values calculated sample size \(n\), \(t(n-1)\) distribution. \((n - 1)\) called degrees freedom t-distribution \[ \begin{aligned} T &\sim t(n-1)\\ T &= \frac{\overline{X}-\mu}{\frac{s}{\sqrt{n}}}\\ \overline{X} &\pm t_{(n-1)}^* \frac{s}{\sqrt{n}}  \end{aligned} \] - \(t_{(n-1)}^*\) number standard errors required desired level confidence \(t_{(n-1)}\) distribution

title: STAT1201 Course Notes
text: \(H_0 : \mu = \mu_0\) \(H_1 : \mu \neq \mu_0\) \(H_0 : \mu = \mu_0\) \(H_1 : \mu > \mu_0\) \(H_0 : \mu = \mu_0\) \(H_1 : \mu < \mu_0\) \[ \begin{aligned} df &= n - 1 \\ se(\overline{X}) &= \frac{s}{\sqrt{n}} \\ t_{stat} &= \frac{\overline{X} - \mu_0}{se(\overline{X})}\\ \overline{X}&\pm t^*\times se(\overline{X}) \end{aligned} \]

text: \(S_p^2\) pooled variance \(\sqrt{S_p^2}\) pooled standard deviation \[ \begin{aligned} df &= n_1 + n_2 -2 \\ S_p^2 &= \frac{s_1^2(n_1 - 1) + s_2^2(n_2 - 1)}{(n_1 - 1) + (n_2 - 1)} \\ se(\overline{X_1} - \overline{X_2}) &= \sqrt{S_p^2\left(\frac{1}{n_1} + \frac{1}{n_2}\right)} \\ t_{stat} &= \frac{(\overline{X_1} - \overline{X_2}) - (\mu_1 - \mu_2)}{se(\overline{X_1} - \overline{X_2})} \\ (\overline{X_1} - \overline{X_2})&\pm t^*\times se(\overline{X_1} - \overline{X_2}) \end{aligned} \]

text: \(p_1\) \(p_2\) unknown population proportions \(\hat{p_1}\) \(\hat{p_1}\) sample proportions \[ \begin{aligned} se(\hat{p_1} - \hat{p_2}) &= \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p_1}(1 - \hat{p_1})}{n_1} + \frac{\hat{p_2}(1 - \hat{p_2})}{n_2}} \\ Z_{stat} &= \frac{(\hat{p_1} - \hat{p_2}) - (p_1 - p_2)}{se(\hat{p_1} - \hat{p_2})} \\ (\hat{p_1} - \hat{p_2}) &\pm Z^*\times se(\hat{p_1} - \hat{p_2}) \end{aligned} \]

title: STAT1201 Course Notes
text: Correlation coefficient \(r\) measures relative strength direction linear relationship two numerical variables. Correlation imply causal effect two variables. \(-1 <= r <= +1\) \(r\) close -1 implies strong negative linear relationship \(r\) close +1 implies strong positive linear relationship \(r\) close 0 implies weak linear relationship \(r = 0\) implies linear relationship Define: \(r\) sample correlation coefficient \(\rho\) population correlation coefficient \[ \begin{aligned} df &= n - 2 \\ se(r) &= \sqrt{\frac{1 - r^2}{n - 2}} \\ t_{stat} &= \sqrt{r - \rho}{se(r)}  \end{aligned} \]

title: STAT1201 Course Notes
text: null alternative hypothesis One Way ANOVA : \(H_0 : \mu_1 = \mu_2 = ... = \mu_k\) (k = . groups) \(H_1 :\) \(\mu_j\)’s . \(H_0\) rejected find population means different. 4 treatment groups “Potato”. \(k = 4\) \[ \begin{aligned} \text{. pairs } &= {k \choose 2} \\ &= \frac{k!}{2!(k-2)!}\\ &= \frac{4}{2!(4 - 2)!} \\ \therefore \text{. pairs } &= 6 \end{aligned} \]
code: potato <- read.csv("data/M9Potato.csv") summary(aov(Yield ~ Treatment, data = potato)) #>             Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value  Pr(>F)    #> Treatment    3  54416   18139   5.773 0.00517 ** #> Residuals   20  62837    3142                    #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

title: STAT1201 Course Notes
text:
Using significance level 5% (\(\alpha = 0.05\)) reject individual null hypothesis p-value less 0.05. Therefore can say \(\mu_A 
eq \mu_B\), \(\mu_A 
eq \mu_C\), \(\mu_C 
eq \mu_D\)
code: pairwise.t.test(potato$Yield, potato$Treatment, p.adjust.method = "none") #>  #>  Pairwise comparisons using t tests with pooled SD  #>  #> data:  potato$Yield and potato$Treatment  #>  #>   A       B       C       #> B 0.02041 -       -       #> C 0.00055 0.12837 -       #> D 0.07778 0.51728 0.03620 #>  #> P value adjustment method: none

title: STAT1201 Course Notes
text: Used contract problem multiple comparisons. Significance = \(\frac{0.05}{q}\), \(q\) number pairs \(\therefore \alpha = \frac{0.05}{6} = 0.0083\) Now \(\mu_A \neq \mu_C\) less \(\alpha\) (0.0083)
code: pairwise.t.test(potato$Yield, potato$Treatment, p.adjust.method = "bonferroni") #>  #>  Pairwise comparisons using t tests with pooled SD  #>  #> data:  potato$Yield and potato$Treatment  #>  #>   A      B      C      #> B 0.1225 -      -      #> C 0.0033 0.7702 -      #> D 0.4667 1.0000 0.2172 #>  #> P value adjustment method: bonferroni

title: STAT1201 Course Notes
text: Bonferroni method little conservative, reducing overall power \(\mu_A \neq \mu_C\) less \(\alpha\) (0.05)

title: STAT1201 Course Notes
text: Odds = \(\frac{p}{1 - p}\) Define p = probability reduction smoking subjects nicotine inhaler \(p = \frac{52}{200} = 0.26\) \(\frac{p}{1-p} = \frac{0.26}{1-0.26} = 0.3514\) Odds reduction smoking subjects nicotine inhaler 0.3514 1 Odds reduction smoking subjects placebo : = \(\frac{\text{Odds}_1}{\text{Odds}_2}\) Based sample data effect inhaler reduction smoking 3.55 times huger someone using nicotine inhaler using placebo inhaler. implies nicotine inhalers beneficial assisting reduction smoking based sample data. Since \(p\) probability, \(0 < \text{Odds} < \infty\) \(-\infty < ln(\frac{p}{1-p}) < \infty\) Odds < 1, \(ln(\frac{p}{1-p})\) negative
code: addmargins(chisq$observed) #>       #>       Nicotine Placebo Sum #>   No       148     182 330 #>   Yes       52      18  70 #>   Sum      200     200 400 logistic_odds(18 / 200) #> [1] 0.0989011 logistic_or(52 / 200, 18 / 200) #> [1] 3.552553

previous_headings: 11 - Chi-square test and Logistic Regression > Logistic Regression
title: STAT1201 Course Notes
text: Population regression model: \(ln(\frac{p}{1-p}) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X\) \(\beta_0\) population intercept \(\beta_1\) slope parameters Estimated model: \(ln(\frac{\hat{p}}{1-\hat{p}}) = b_0 + b_1 X\)

previous_headings: 11 - Chi-square test and Logistic Regression > Logistic Regression > Inferences
title: STAT1201 Course Notes
text: Logistic regression fits “S” shaped logistic function. curve goes - 1. curve tells us probability person getting lung cancer based number cigarettes per day. \[ \begin{aligned} \hat{p} &= \frac{e^{b_0 + b_1X}}{1 + e^{b_0 + b_1X}} \\ \\ \therefore \hat{p} &= \frac{e^{-12.5974 + 0.7630X}}{1 + e^{-12.5974 + 0.7630X}}\\ \\ \text{} X &= 15 \end{aligned} \]
code: lungs <- read.csv("data/M11Lungs.csv") lungs$Cancer <- ifelse(lungs$Cancer == "Yes", 1, 0)  library(popbio) logi.hist.plot(lungs$Cigarettes, lungs$Cancer,   boxp = FALSE,   ylabel = "Prob of lung cancer",   xlabel = "No. of cigarettes smoked" ) summary(glm(Cancer ~ Cigarettes, data = lungs, family = "binomial")) #>  #> Call: #> glm(formula = Cancer ~ Cigarettes, family = "binomial", data = lungs) #>  #> Deviance Residuals:  #>     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max   #> -2.6295  -0.4043  -0.2510   0.5282   1.6895   #>  #> Coefficients: #>             Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)     #> (Intercept) -12.5974     3.6584  -3.443 0.000575 *** #> Cigarettes    0.7630     0.2263   3.371 0.000749 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1) #>  #>     Null deviance: 52.925  on 39  degrees of freedom #> Residual deviance: 28.312  on 38  degrees of freedom #> AIC: 32.312 #>  #> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 5 # Estimated probability for getting lung cancer for a person who smokes 15 cigarettes per day. phat <- logistic_phat(-12.5974, 0.7630, 15) phat #> [1] 0.240051  # Odds for getting lung cancer for a person who smokes 15 cigarettes per day. logistic_odds(phat) #> [1] 0.3158778

title: STAT1201 Course Notes
code: # Differences in heights between 15 pairs of plants # 15.6, -21.3, 2.5, 5.1, 1.9, 7.3, 8.9, 13.0, 4.4, 9.2, 17.8, 7.6, 23.8, 19.1, -15.2  # Define p = P(Cross-fertilized pants taller) # H0: p = 0.5 # H1: p > 0.5  # If H0 is true, each pair would have a 0.5 chance of having cross # fertilized plants taller.  # Define X = Number of pairs that the cross fertilized plant is taller # X ~ Binom(15, 0.5)  # From the data we observe that X = 13 (because 13 pairs are positive) # P(X >= 13) sum(dbinom(13:15, prob = 0.5, 15)) #> [1] 0.003692627

title: STAT1201 Course Notes
text: Test paired matched data. powerful sign test. Uses information sets scores sign test. Looks sign also magnitude Signed-Rank statistic, \(S\) \(S\) = sum ranks corresponding positive differences

title: STAT1201 Course Notes
text: \[ \begin{aligned} E(S) &= \frac{n(n+1)}{4} \\ sd(S) &= \sqrt{\frac{n(n+1)(2n + 1)}{24}} \\ Z &= \frac{S-E(S)}{sd(S)} \end{aligned} \]

title: STAT1201 Course Notes
code: # Differences in heights between 15 pairs of plants # 15.6, -21.3, 2.5, 5.1, 1.9, 7.3, 8.9, 13.0, 4.4, 9.2, 17.8, 7.6, 23.8, 19.1, -15.2 # # Take the absolute differences and then rank them # Absolute differences # 15.6, 21.3, 2.5, 5.1, 1.9, 7.3, 8.9, 13.0, 4.4, 9.2, 17.8, 7.6, 23.8, 19.1, 15.2 # # Ranked absolute differences # 11, 14, 2, 4, 1, 5, 7, 9, 3, 8, 12, 6, 15, 13, 10 # S <- 11 + 2 + 4 + 1 + 5 + 7 + 9 + 3 + 8 + 12 + 6 + 15 + 13 S #> [1] 96 # # H0 : median difference in plant growth is 0 # H1 : median difference in plant growth is positive # # P(S >= 96) signed_rank(S, 15, tail = 1) #>  #> 1-Sided Signed Rank Test  #>  #>   S E(S)    sd(S)   z.stat    p.value evidence #>  96   60 17.60682 2.044663 0.02044407 moderate  rank_assumptions() #> Normal Approximation #> If the number of pairs is such that (n(n+1))/2 is large enough (> 20), #>     a normal approximation can be used

title: STAT1201 Course Notes
text: Nonparametric version o two sample t-test compare whether distributions two samples similar shape \(H_0\) : difference distributions samples \(H_1\) : distributions different \(W\) = sum ranks observations target sample \(n_1\) = sample size whose ranks summing. \(n_2\) = sample size group \[ \begin{aligned} E(W) &= \frac{n_1(n_1 + n_2 + 1)}{2} \\ sd(W) &= \sqrt{\frac{n_1 n_2 (n_1 + n_2 + 1)}{12}} \\ Z &= \frac{W - E(W)}{sd(W)} \end{aligned} \]

title: STAT1201 Course Notes
code: # Change in pulse rates (bpm) # Caff    17, 22, 21, 16,  6, -2, 27, 15, 16, 20 # Decaff   4, 10,  7, -9,  5,  4,  5,  7,  6, 12  # H0 : There is no difference between the distributions of the #      caffeinated and decaffeinated samples  # H1 : The distribution of the caffeinated sample shifted to the right #      of the decaffeinated sample  # Rank the data from smallest to largest # Caff    16, 19, 18, 14.5, 7.5, 2, 20, 13, 14.5, 17 # Decaff  3.5, 11, 9.5, 1, 5.5, 3.5, 5.5, 9.5, 7.5, 12  # W = sum of the ranks for observations from caffeinated sample. W <- 16 + 19 + 18 + 14.5 + 7.5 + 2 + 20 + 13 + 14.5 + 17 W #> [1] 141.5  # p = P(W >= 141.5) rank_sum(W, 10, 10, tail = 1) #>  #> 1-Sided Rank-Sum Test (Wilcoxon)  #>  #>      W E(W)    sd(W)   z.stat    p.value evidence #>  141.5  105 13.22876 2.759141 0.00289768   strong
